question: Treatment of choice for pseudotumor
exp: Steroids are the treatment of choice for pseudotumor Orbital Pseudotumor Most common cause of painful orbital mass, present like tumor histopathology - Polymorphous lymphoid infiltrate with varied amount of fibrosis Optic nerve compression may occur in massive posterior involvement May lead to frozen orbit in cases of chronic involvement and fibrosis More common seen unilaterally On MRI sequences it has both Muscle belly + Tendon involvement Rx: Oral prednisolone after confirmation is treatment of choice. Radiotherapy, methotrexate and. TNF alpha inhibitors are used in recalcitrant cases

question: Which of the following structure(s) is/are preserved in enucleation?
exp: Exenteration All the contents of orbit with its periorbital tissue, appendages, eyelids is removed Indications are rapidly spreading life threatening malignant tumors like sebaceous cell carcinoma, advanced retinoblastoma, melanomas, rhinocerebral mucormycosis Reconstruction of eye socket with lattisimus dorsi or pectoralis major flap can be done afterwards Enucleation Refers to excision of the eyeball. Can be performed under L. A in adults and under G. A in children. Evisceration Removal of the contents of the eyeball leaving behind the sclera Orbitotomy Refers to surgical approach for an orbital mass lesion 4 types: anterior orbitotomy, Lateral orbitotomy, Transfrontal orbitotomy, Temporofrontal orbitotomy

question: Which of the following is a feature of Treacher Collins syndrome?
exp: Coloboma of eyelid is one of the ocular feature of Treacher Collins syndrome Mandibulofacial dysostosis ( aka Treacher Collins syndrome) Refers to a condition resulting from hypoplasia of zygoma and mandible. Features of Treacher Collins syndrome: * Indistinct inferior orbital margin * Coloboma of the lower eyelid * Anti-mongoloid slant * Macrostomia with high-arched palate * External ear deformity * Bird-like face.

question: 24-12-6 rule is applied for
exp: Safe surgical exploration distances during orbitotomy Safe distances for the periorbital dissection from the intact outside rim of the adult orbit to vital interior structures are specified in millimeters. Generally an exploration depth of 25 mm along the lateral and inferior walls is regarded as safe. A 30 mm distance from the supraorbital rim and the anterior lacrimal crest are also considered safe exposure of the roof and the medial wall respectively. Along the medial wall, impoant landmarks are described as measurements from the anterior lacrimal crest: - 24 mm* to the anterior ethmoidal foramen - 36 mm* to the posterior ethmoidal foramen (12 mm from the anterior ethmoidal foramen) - 42 mm* to the optic canal (6 mm from the posterior ethmoidal foramen) * Mnemotechnic formula (rule of halves): 24-12-6.
